Contains minor character arc spoilers. But you'd probably see them coming, this isn't an M. Night Shyamalan-style anime.
One theme that stands out from this anime is "normalcy". This anime makes the otherwise hyper-violent, zany world of Soul Eater and makes the world, the art, the characters, the base concepts seem completely "normal". This is a lighthearted anime that's great for burning 4 hours.
Story (7): "Normal". Very. We see very low-stakes situations that feed a minor inter-personal conflict between our main trio, eventually leading up to a final confrontation and resolution that takes place alongside a final boss-battle. At least stuff happens in some sort ofarc, they're not just sitting around talking about boys. Or bread. A lot of slice-of-life shows fail to deliver a narrative arc. This one's not terrible.


Art (7): The art was technically competent and totally "normal". Nothing unusual in the art at all, nothing experimental. The stitched-up zig-zags from Soul Eater are gone, replaced with "normal" looking buildings. Even the cartoonish-looking school is drawn through normal eyes, as if the viewer/narrator has not witnessed the raw insanity that is present in this world.


There were no weird shot compositions, or at least none that stand out in my mind. The animation was decent, I didn't notice any significantly stuttering areas. The action scenes MAY have had some stutter due to the inherently non-action focus of the anime, but I wasn't overly aware of it. The quality was consistently "good". The "outside" backgrounds were a typical school-esque design, and the inside of the main trio's room was well detailed. As the seasons change, the trio puts decorations on their walls and desks that let you know they are way too excited about Halloween.


The character designs were unique within this series. The world's amazing lack of dress code means that each member of the trio is able to be fully expressed artistically in the day-to-day interactions, as opposed to the mere "accessorizing" that a lot of slice-of-life anime characters seem to do.


Sound (7): I'm not particularly familiar with voice-actors or bands. I can't speak to the particular voice-actors' histories, or the particular bands' histories in relation to their work here or anything along those lines.


What I can say is this: The opening and ending songs fit with the overall theme, opening on an upbeat number about... something. It wasn't subtitled. The ending was a slower that closed down the show well, singing about friendship and togetherness, people being there for each other. I don't think either song was incredibly memorable or inspirational, but they fit the theme.


The character's voices fit similarly well, and there were no oddities in the voice portrayal of the character that would either hint that there was more to their character than their face value or hint that the VA simply didn't understand the character.


Character (9): Each member of the main trio is appropriately unique, and the side characters are fairly fleshed out. Characters that appear here from Soul Eater reprise their roles and typical interactions, with one exception. Liz and Patty differ quite notably from their main-line selves, but their role given here fits into the story without any oddities.


Of the main trio, we see all of them develop somewhat over the course of the series. It's not a particularly huge development arc in each case, but one can't expect too much from a fluffy show like this with only 12 episodes to work with.


We're introduced to our main, Tsugumi, a "weapon", who discovers her powers after putting her spear-leg through a kitchen cabinet. She reacts to this as most normal people would, and after she goes to the school, she reacts to the school situations as most people would. She's not "cowardly" by any stretch of the imagination, and after a confrontation with some baddies, she worries about her inability to act. At the end of the series, she comes into her own, obtains her resolve and picks her meister.


The other two members of her trio face minor troubles, one having to face her royal identity head-on and make her own choices instead of being sheltered, and the other having to face her own inability to remember even the most recent thing she's done. They also have to face off against each other, as they both want Tsugumi as their own weapon.


Our main villain is villain-ey enough for an SOL anime that happens to have a violent conflict sub-plot mixed in at the end. The only motivation this character could realistically need is given to us all throughout the show. "Shibusen and witches are natural enemies." She doesn't see much of an arc, she's merely there to drive the interpersonal conflict in the trio to an accelerated conclusion. It works, I guess, but in the end, it serves to remind us that this IS Soul Eater's world, where violent conflict between these two groups is "normal", one side doesn't really need a valid reason to hate the other, that's just how it's always been.


Enjoyment (10): Yeah. I liked it. I marathon'd it in the middle of a school week. It's a light, fluffy anime that delivers a dose of everyday life into the insane world of Soul Eater. I saw this 4 years after I saw the original Soul Eater, so I wasn't expecting a whole lot of Soul Eater in this anime. If you expect an explicit prequel to Soul Eater that matches in tone and themes, then you'll likely hate this anime.


One point I'd like to properly make: This anime showed me that weapons are people, too. Soul Eater FAILED to establish that in any way, shape or form for me. Soul Eater's characters are so incredibly zany, we see them mostly in weapon form (as it is an action show), and we very rarely see them doing normal, "boring" human things that it's easy to miss out on significant aspects of the weapons as human characters. Conversely, Tsugumi's default is her human form, and we see her interacting with people in human ways and not in combat situations. We see her react to stressful situations as most people would as well, lending some credibility to her character as a human in a very human-focused show.


This show will be pretty memorable for me, not for the story, but for the characters and the alternate-take on an already very memorable show.


Overall (8): It's not too bad, just don't go into it expecting Soul Eater. It's only 4 hours, and there are certainly worse anime you could drop 4 hours on.

Have you ever been so confused by something that you’re almost rendered speechless by it? The kind of reaction where you’re so dumbfounded by a choice made, so utterly perplexed at the thought process that’s gone into a decision, that all you can do is raise your hands in surrender and mouth “Why?” over and over again in hopes that some all-seeing god will provide you an answer for the impossible puzzle you’re faced with? Because that was my reaction pretty much throughout the entirety of Soul Eater NOT, the prequel spin-off to Soul Eater. Every single choice that went into this side story bafflesme so completely than in lieu of a more traditional review, I am forced to collect my thoughts in the form of an imagined dialogue between two Studio Bones executives as they come to the conclusions that birthed this mystifyingly wrong-headed experiment. Maybe I can make some sense of it that way. Probably not, though.


Executive A: Hey, so Soul Eater’s been out for like five years and it’s got a pretty good fanbase. What say we put out some sort of spinoff to keep the brand name strong?


Executive B: That sounds like a very good idea. So, what kind of spinoff? A sequel could be a good idea, you get to see the characters you love a bit more grown up and going on to new challenges.


A: No, a prequel makes far more sense. We get to explore the world more fully and talk about all those ancillary environmental details that were only in the background before. Like, we can explore the city more fully!


B: You sure? It feels like we’re missing a lot of opportunities that way, considering how well-formed the world and characters already were at the start of Soul Eater. Our audience already knows the layout well enough, we don’t need to get stuck in pedantic detail-mongering. Also, if it’s a prequel, we don’t get to use Crona, a.k.a. the best character in the show by far.


A: That’s okay, we’ll just make up some original characters and tell a completely new story with them! And the main cast can act as cameos so they don’t wear out their welcome.


B: I... feel like that could still work as a sequel, but okay. Prequel it is. So, who are our new characters?


A: Well, they’re a trio of cute girls. Tsumugi, the lead, says “Gagantous!” a lot. Meme forgets literally everything. Anya is a spoiled rich girl obsesses with commoner stuff.


B: Okay, what else?


A: That’s it. That’s the extent of their characters.


B: What? Why? They’re all so thinly sketched, defined by cheap gimmicks rather than goals and personalities people can get attached to. How is our audience supposed to care about them when there’s nothing to care about?


A: Because they’re in a lesbian love triangle.


B: ...really? So we’re going the yuri route?


A: Yeah, I was thinking it should be a yuri slice-of-life. Maybe get a little action-y and classic Soul Eater for the climax, but this should be its own thing. Also, we’ll see Jacqueline and Kim from the original show, and they’ll be gay for each other too.


B: Huh. Well, that’s definitely a risk. Our audience is used to the shonen action spectacle stuff, they might not like such a vast departure. But hey, if we pull it off well enough, might make for a nice change of pace! What kinds of cool things will out characters do?


A: Work at a cafe.


B: You’re shitting me.


A: Nope.


B: That’s, like, the laziest possible thing they could do.


A: But maid uniforms!


B: Who cares about maid uniforms? Soul Eater isn’t a fanservice vehicle. I mean, there was a little of it in the early parts, but we made a conscious effort to tone that stuff down to avoid alienating a broader audience, remember?


A: Listen, audiences want to be pandered to. So in this spin-off, not only will there be maid uniforms, there’ll be plenty of panty shots too! And the girls won’t be able to stop talking about each other’s boobs! That’s what everyone wants!


B: No, it isn’t! That spits in the face of the admirable restraint we showed making Soul Eater! Is that the only reason you want it to be yuri, so you can contrive excuses for the girls to get all touchy-feely with each other for dudes to drool over?


A: Yup! What, you thought we were actually gonna try to get some good, honest LGBT representation in there?


B: Kind of, yeah!


A: Well, you’re wrong. We want the dudes who think lesbian action is hot to enjoy this, but still imagine making it with them. That’s why we’ll make all the ecchi feel as contrived un-genuine as possible so they aren’t scared off thinking these girls might legitimately not be available to them. Also, we’ll half-heartedly pretend Tsugumi’s got a crush on a dude for a bit just for backup.


B: That feels so disrespectful in every conceivable sense. And stupid. You think people are gonna enjoy such half-hearted measures?


A: But wait! There’s more!


B: Oh god, what now?


A: We’ll also animate this entire show in the most boring, pedestrian way possible with shitty, generic backgrounds and plasticky, sub-Love Live faces. No crative cinematography or editing, just bland and vapid static shots over bland and vapid locations and dialogue.


B: Oh, FUCK that! No! That’s enough! That is the stupidest idea I ever heard! Soul Eater was such a great show because of how stylish it was! It had a unique and expressive aesthetic that was full personality and creativity! Every shot had something interesting happening! Every visual choice was carefully made to make every single moment stick out in your mind! It had some of the most consistently engaging, kinetic visual storytelling ever, even outside of the action scenes! Replacing all that with shitty, sub-basement moe aesthetics completely destroys the core appeal of the show we’re supposed to be honoring here!


A: But moe is very in now! That experimental, creative stuff is all passe. Everyone will love it!


B: No. No one will love it. Yuri fans will hate that it doesn’t commit to the yuri, slice of life fans will hate that there isn’t any creativity in the scenarios, Soul Eater fans will hate how different it feels from the show they’ve come to love, and casual anime watchers who stumble across it will hate how lazily put together it is. Soul Eater managed to appeal to pretty much everyone. The spin-off you’re describing appeals to NO ONE.


A: You sure? Because I already got funding approved for it and we’ve started production.


B: HOW?!?!?!


A: Hey, calm down. Tell you what, since you’ve got so many opinions on it, I’ll at least let you name it. That can be your contribution.


B: *long, beleaguered sigh* Okay, fine. I guess we’re doing this. But mark my words, this is going to be a massive flop that everyone should stay away from. And to make sure the audience knows what to expect, we’re gonna call it Soul Eater NOT, because they should NOT watch it.


A: Wow, that’s a little mean, don’t you think?


B: Trust me, they’ll thank us for warning them.



Yeah, that’s how I imagine it went down. It’s the only way I can make sense of how wrong-headed this entire production was. Soul Eater NOT fails as yuri, it fails as slice-of-life, it fails as a Soul Eater property, and it fails on its own merits by being lifeless, inert, and vapid every step of the way. Don’t bother watching it; it’s not worth it, even for the irony. Now to watch Soul Eater episode 21 to wash the taste out of my mouth.

WARNING SPOILER
If you thought that Soul Eater was good then you've come to the wrong place. When the first episode came out, most people were ambivalent to the series since they thought it was going to have the same style as the Soul Eater anime, but it did not. I only read the manga and I did not watch the anime. However, I found the series to be enjoyable as it focused more of the slice days of life than rather than action
Plot
The main character Tsugami has been chosen to go to Soul Eater Academy since she can turned into a weapon. There she meets two meinster candidates in which she has to choose one of them to be her weaponmaster. The rest of the series focuses on daily lives of those three plus more character development for some characters who did not get that much in the main soul eater series. Plus, it seems that there is a mysterious enemy brewing trouble in the academy.


Characters


You got the optimistic girl Tsugami, tsundere princess Anya, and a forgetful girl Meme. These three girls form a tight relationship as they sleep in the same dorm and work together. One of the main problems that Tsugami has that she has to choose a meinster candidate either from Anya or Meme. It is a tough choice since they become really good friends over the course of the series, and it gets harder and harder for her to choose, as one of them is going to go let down. Some of the original Soul Eater characters get a cameo like Moka. Another unique thing is that  some of the side characters from the main series get more character development and more screen time in this series. We learn more about them more in this series before the main story Soul Eater comes later.


Sound


I loved the Op of this series. It gives the watchers a good senses of what the series is going to be, a lot of fun, but a sense of danger.


Animation


The animation has been fairly standard, and nothing too crazy from the original Soul Eater Anime. However, there could have more action scenes, and action could have been better animated. I found the character designs unique and resembles the wackiness of Soul Eater Not!


Enjoyment


In all, I found the series to be really enjoyable. Some of the negatives I found was that the the main antagonist could have done more in the beginning and not everything at the very end. The show went very lighthearted to some grim moments at the end. Otherwise, it has been a good ride.

While not as great as the original Soul Eater, it does have a lot of great back story and a deeper look into the life of a weapon, their schooling, their transformation, picking a partner, life at the academy, etc. It's like taking a magnifying glass to the original show and I'm glad I watched it. There's definitely a LOT less Black Star, which is a definite plus. It also gives you a closer look into the past lives of the Thompson sisters. This show definitely strayed away from the mystery and action of Soul Eater and added a lot more of the slice oflife feel but it's definitely worth watching.

Soul Eater NOT is, well, not Soul Eater. However, i like it even more than the original series, because it not only gave me actual details on how a lot of the supernatural mechanics worked, but came from the prospective of someone completely new to weapons and meisters and all that nonsense.
Story: 7: This is a Moe/Sol deal, not your action/shounen like the original series... And you know what? I loved it. The MC discovers she has the ability to transform into a weapon and transfers to DWMA, Where she finds herself quickly befriending Maka-sempai and two other new students, both meisters, some stuff happensand some very surprising plot twists take place. The later parts VS the witch are quite a lot like the regular Soul Eater, but it still always feels slightly more lighthearted.


Art: 8: It's NOT Soul Eater!!!! While the style of the original series fit it's themes very well, i still hated it. This style fits this anime better and doesn't look terrible, which is always good.


Sound: 7: Never really stood out, either for better or worse... The OP is pretty good though


Character: 8 : This is a character-focused show, so naturally the characters are all really detailed, maybe slightly above average for a 12-episode show, but these guys are LIKABLE, which is a really important trait many shows are missing. Even the character following the dumb, forgetful stereotype for most of the anime, never pushes it far enough to annoy even me, someone who loathes stupid characters almost as much as i do arrogant ones.


Enjoyment: 9: Much like Fate/Prisma Ilya, there is a strong yuri vibe in the 'downtime', when annoyances such as the plot are taking a rest, and to a slightly lesser degree this exists for the same purpose as Kaleid: Fun. The story isn't supposed to move you to tears or anything, it's supposed to just be a fun, interesting show with a touch of action and yuri.

Ok so I am a die hard fan of the Original Soul Eater its what got me into anime in the first place. So when I saw this spin off after watching the original I was so excited especially because it had 3 main female cast and had a Yuri spin. I barely got through the first episode the humor was trash, the animation is dog shit( maybe because I was used to the original animation), and the characters were lazy and flat. Maybe if it was really separate from the original( meaning not showing the original characters) then I wouldn't be so mad.

For people going into this, please understand this is a completely different series than the show it's a spinoff from. 
A lot of people hate this show because...
"It's the main show but neutered"....
This isn't a dark battle focused series like its predecessor. This show has a more girly moe-ish art style and the story is closer to a slice of life anime that does expand the universe a bt. 
It's a bit prequel that takes place before the main series. 
I would give examples to point out how it's a prequel, but those would be spoilers. 
If you like animes that have cute girls goingthroughout their school life with some fanservice, you might like this show. \n\n
Watching it with an opened mind it's a cute show and I loved the cameos from the original cast and them actually interacting with the main girls, instead of making short appearences only to never be seen again.\n

Well, what can I say? The guidelines told me to focus on the anime and not comment on the reviews of others, but I think that will be pivotal in writing a review straight from the soul. I'm honestly bad at being a critique since I ramble and sometimes let my biases get the best of me, but keeping that in mind let's get started.
  I genuinely like Soul Eater Not. It is a cute slice of life version of Soul Eater equipped with a new cast of main and side characters while still retaining appearances of old characters with cameosnow and then despite it being a prequel. The story wasn't anything spectacular. In fact it had trouble fitting some plot points in and sewing everything neatly together since it only had 12 episodes to work with, not uncommon. It was fairly smooth for the most part, but of course mixing a slightly comedic slice of life-esque genre with the more supernatural action that was the main installment of Soul Eater is no easy feat. It requires the right balance which they didn't seem to nail, but weren't completely off with. The art and animation was nothing out of the ordinary or unique either it seemed, but it was beautiful and clean nonetheless. I never pay much attention to the OST, but I always give the opening a try, can't say much for endings (I usually jump right to the next episode). What I can say is that it was very lighthearted and accentuated the cute style they had. It was a nice song when paired with the visuals even made someone like me feel for it a bit. Though the amount of sweetness in the anime was close to giving me diabetes I have seen far worse. The characters were for the most part unique and flowed well together. Noticing how each step of the story was all about building bonds and friendship was both stale and enjoyable at the same time somehow. Though they didn't have enough time to completely draw these highlights out. I can say that it was weird watching an anime like this, however I didn't necessarily dislike it. Usually in a more action based anime (which is what I prefer) I get bored with the dialogue and interactions between the characters for the most part. This anime was obviously more dialogue than action, but I enjoyed the interactions between characters regardless of whether I liked them or not, as that also plays a factor in my interest in dialogue. When the action came along too it was flatter as to be expected of the less action oriented anime, but that wasn't bad either. It felt rushed and had a bit of ass pull in there, but by the end I had fun with it. It was a mixed box of surprises, plot, and emotion. That's what you should expect when walking into this anime. (This is the part where I talk about other things) 

   If you are a Soul Eater fan or if you are a slice of life fan it shouldn't matter too much. It seems like everyone is picking sides with this anime and that's exactly why I decided to write this. It's an anime so you should look at it as an anime fan. I think as a Soul Eater anime it is lacking, I think as a slice of life it is passable (though I don't watch too many of those). However as an anime I think it is a breathe of unique air doing it's own thing and it should be respected for it. It doesn't seem to fit in if you are trying to put a label on it, but maybe somewhere down the line it will have a label all it's own. I hope more anime decide to take liberties like this and be something special, something on it's own regardless of how rushed or half-assed or whether it technically belongs to a specific franchise. Anime should be viewed as it is and it itself should be seen not the critiques or the overcasting forebearers that set the stage for it. Soul Eater Not is a unique though not outstanding anime, but it sure makes it's own individual footprint on the long beach of anime in front and behind us. I hope you give it a try if you want to watch something sweet and new.



(spoiler)

Also to those who complained about the "winning with friendship" cliche at the end, keep in mind if you are a returning fan of Soul Eater that that's how that series ended too! So shut it. Soul Eater is all about friendship is magic among other cliches that inhabit both the original and Not. If you can't put up with that, don't watch it.

Unpopular opinion: Soul Eater NOT! gets more hate than it deserves. 
I understand most were looking forward to watching something strongly related to the original series, but even the tittle suggests it's NOT happening. I mean you get a warning STRAIGHT AWAY, so why even bother if you already know it's NOT what you're expecting to find?
Story: 6/10
The story is quite distant from the original Soul Eater, and is much more laid back, less packed with action and, unlike the original, aimed rather at the female audience. In my opinion, the creators intentionally aimed at the lighter themes and slice of life genre, given thefact the story takes place before the main series, when things in Shibusen get quite tense. It would seem the story starts developing only by the end, but when you give it a second thought, you realize things were leading towards the final along the entire anime. Only, ugh, it was so vague you have to dig in quite deep to figure those things out. It's not necessary a bad thing, but with the animes that don't ask much of thinking, I prefer not to think much over. 


On one hand, I'm keen to think it would be more plot driven had it the similar amount of episodes as the first Soul Eater did, but then I highly doubt I'd have patience to watch 50 bloody episodes of it. 12 is probably the best number after all. The story is so light and almost non-existent I was cleaning my laptop with Soul Eater NOT! playing as a background, yet I followed the plot. It's only two last episodes that demanded my full attention. Here comes the confusion of mine - theoretically, I'm glad it demanded so little dedication - it's been a while since I'd watch a relaxing anime which would allow me to go brain numb and giggle at silly jokes. On the other hand, I love plots and Soul Eater NOT! had not really developed any until a couple of the last episodes.  Rating story is quite difficult with this one due to near absence of it. But, meh, it did follow some pattern and covered most of things, so I guess it deserves a medium score.


Art: 9/10


Although I LOVED the original Soul Eater, the drawing style there was constantly pissing me off. ESPECIALLY how little effort they put into character shoes, making them look just like lumps of colors and lines, not to mention being terribly disproportional. The colouring was an entire different story...Therefore Soul Eater NOT! actually pleased me with the art quality. Say all you want about how it was no longer unique, but I seriously preferred it over the original style. Remember, kids - unique does not mean good, and in this case I prefer the generic anime style of popular shite rather than the original Soul Eater art. This season had most of the original characters hanging around casually (although I definitely missed the reaper himself), and that was truly flattering to see them keep the unique traits only in the better quality. Usually, when upgrading quality, animes tend to redesign the characters and it ruins them most of time, so I'm grateful to the old gods and the new for regarding the old designs in here.


Sound: 8/10


The opening matched the theme of the anime very well. It was as light and carefree as the series themselves. Just like the tittle, it suggested it won't be exactly the Soul Eater we'd expect to find, and rather something of a filler season. The song itself was quite addictive, although I did not take liking in it at first. The ending was fine. Most of time I watch both, but here I was skipping the ending, because meh. It's one of the animes I'd watch at home and not while working out, so ending was optional, unlike most of time. What made me truly happy was music in the anime itself. Usually I get annoyed when characters start singing (Guilty Crown, ugh.), but for once I've changed my views. The songs were not so irritating and the voice actors performed them well, therefore it actually turned into a pleasant experience. Heads up for that! 


Characters: 4/10


Here I will agree with the most of people - it sucked. The only concept I liked was Tsugumi defining herself as a "girl who's in love with love", as it's rare for the main characters to acknowledge their problems. I liked Anya's outfit and her fetish of buying crap, but that's about it. Her being all noble and then tearing up the other moment for a silly reason was ehh? But the worst of them all was Meme. I don't give a flying heck that she was possessed and it caused her dumb behaviour - it was getting on my nerves, along with the slow talking manner and general denseness. A person like this would not survive and ffs, people like this don't make friends, not as easily at least. I did enjoy the episode of her winning in casino, but that's about it - all the other time I was annoyed with her, and actually yelled "YES", when Tsugumi finally snapped at her. The other characters were shite as well. No one expects development in this kind of anime, but leaving nothing but blank shells roaming around the anime, such as Clay, Akane or Cana is no good. Explain me purpose of Cana, someone? Well, there is none. She's just a random very young character who does "fortune telling" no one cares about and it makes no sense. Is she even a student? No one knows. AND THIS IS NOT OKAY. The only thing that sorta saves the score from being fully negative is the original characters of Soul Eater. Stein alone brings it to a new level. He is generally my babe, but in this season he was a star. Also I liked how much Sid was featured and how this sub-story merged into the original series....Which still wasn't too smooth, as although we see Sid die by the end (which happens in the early episodes of Soul Eater), his death reasons named in the earlier series are different. In Soul Eater, he dies by hands of a witch and on a mission, while in Soul Eater NOT! the story of his death is quite different.


Enjoyment: 7/10


I followed my own advice and opened my mind to not expecting the series to even resemble the original anime. It helped a big time. Usually I watch anime in gym, but I saved this one for home viewing, mostly when doing house chores as it did not demand for my full attention yet I was capable of following it. I did enjoy it to quite some extent, although usually I struggle with animes of the kind and end up suffering whilst attempting to complete it. Surprisingly, Soul Eater NOT! went very smooth with me and I did not experience hardships completing it. It's easy to say I did enjoy it, but had it required more of a focus, I'd probably not. Hence why I can't really rate it very high, but a lower score would be uncalled for as I experienced no discomfort either.


Overall: 7/10


As I've said in the beginning, this anime gets more hate than it deserves. It's definitely not perfect, but let's face the fact the most seem to dislike it for it doesn't meet their expectations of being a proper prequel of Soul Eater. And that, my friends, is why the tittle says 'NOT' in the capital letters and even has an exclamation mark - so you know that what you expect is NOT what you should be expecting. The anime was not designed to be of the same genre as the original franchise, even if it takes place in the same universe. It lacked action and was more focused on slice of life on purpose. The original series did not tell us much about life in Shibusen nor the universe itself, did they? And this season did. Instead, unlike Soul Eater, it did not have much tension and fights. While those two animes are related, they should not be viewed as the same for they are different in so many aspects. Embrace the fact. Open your mind. Maybe then you can find something good about it.

Soul Eater NOT! is an anime that's not particularly good but receives much more flack than it probably deserves thanks to its relation to the far superior Soul Eater. 
Story: 6/10
The plot is... okay. It doesn't really break any new ground, with the whole "two girls want to be with me and I can't decide which one I want" plot-line being established in episode 1. Oddly enough, this plot-line is established minutes after the main character, Tsugumi, meets her suitors, so to speak. She's had a short conversation with Meme and a rather unpleasant interaction with Anya, hardly basis for such a dilemma. As theplot moves on it gets reasonably interesting, with Tsugumi learning how to become a weapon, something we never got to see in Soul Eater, and a villain, which I didn't expect in an anime that tries to emulate slice-of-life. 


Art: 7/10

I quite liked the art style. The main characters from Soul Eater don't change much other than Maka's eyes, and the fight scenes are mostly pretty good, discounting an embarrassing moment near the end of Episode 7. 


Sound: 5/10

I didn't notice other than the opening theme. I'm bad at the sound department. 


Characters: 5/10

The characters are characters. Tsugumi has the most variation, though she has an annoying habit of saying she's "In love with love" despite never actually showing that. She just kind of says it and expects us to accept it as truth. Meme is forgetful. Now you know Meme. Anya is a tsundere rich girl who knows martial arts. Admittedly, she does get some cool scenes here and there but her personality when she's not fighting pretty much amounts to "I don't know the value of money and also I am the tsundere archetype." There are a few other minor characters, with my favorite being Clay, the guy who's smart but not very quick on his feet so whenever someone asks him what he's doing and he has to come up with an excuse, he says he's in love with someone. 


Enjoyment: 6/10

I happened to be in the mood for a cute slice-of-life anime with action thrown in there, and Soul Eater NOT! largely delivered on that. It's not a particularly good anime, but it gave me what I wanted in a decent manner.


Overall: 6/10

Soul Eater NOT! is not a particularly good anime. At the same time, it's not really as bad as everyone makes it out to be. It has its upsides and it shows some stuff that Soul Eater never got around to. None of the main characters in Soul Eater ever have trouble learning how to turn into weapons, they know how at the beginning of the series. Seeing a character learn how to do that was pretty nice. It shows how Sid became a zombie and what the Thompson sisters were doing before Kid officially partnered with them. It also goes a long way toward showing what the other students at the school do, since looking at Soul Eater's main characters is like looking at the Justice League and saying "that's what humans are." Seeing the NOT class has its merits. Overall, Soul Eater NOT! is a great way to get yourself motivated to watch Soul Eater again. That's pretty much what it does best.

An intriguing spin on the Soul Eater franchise, to say the least. I'm going to go out on a limb  and say this could have been so much better if the writers actually had more episodes to work with. They set up a lot of potentially intriguing character development only to be abruptly cut off in the end. The development of the new characters thus felt choked, and it's hard to be invested in any of them, especially since ample screen time was given to cameos from the original series. A lot of the plot points were also interesting,  but alas, came outhalf baked because of the limited format. 8 more episodes and these writers could have wrapped up something special, but when life gives you lemons...\n\n
The inexplicably large proportion of yuri moe fluff felt forced at times, especially in light of how the series ended. It had to have been some bizarre upper management mandate to force itself into a market it didn't exactly fit in. I didn't even mind the art style change, which I thought would have been an interesting choice, had the series turned out better. As a huge fan of the original series, I can see that a lot of talent went into this work, but ultimately it was dulled by what can only be described as a money grab by the owners of the IP to start selling merchandise to the moe market. Disappointing,  but there's definitely enough there for fans of the series and Manga to enjoy.

I read the reviews before watching this show so I was a little bit tentative, but I have to say they were ALL WRONG!
Soul Eater NOT! Is nothing like Soul Eater, which is probably the main reason it gets such a bad rep, as most people are expecting another Soul Eater, it is not. Soul Eater NOT! Is the cutesy, moe. mahou shoujo story based in the Soul Eater universe. 
It revolves around three adorable girls, one is a weapon and the other two are meisters. The three characters have really likeable personalities, and you become attached to them. Meme is a forgetful meister whosleepwalk,, and Anya is a Princess trying to live the life of a “commoner”. While watching I could not decide which character I wanted Tsugumi, the cute weapon who is nervous about going to DWMA, to choose as her meister. \n
The villain in Soul Eater NOT! is a very interesting, beautifully designed witch, and I thought it was a very cool addition to the show. \n
The characters from Soul Eater who showed up were all thrown in in really cool ways, for example Tsugumi and her two meisters met Patty and Liz before they were Death the Kids weapons. I love that friendship, creating more dimensions to the Soul Eater world while still creating something that is its own entity. \n
I only like Soul Eater, it was not one of my favorite animes. But for a cute moe anime with a nice plot and good characters I would recommend anyone to watch Soul Eater NOT! \n
The only people I wouldn’t recommend it to are the ones who have already seen Soul Eater and are expecting that from it, because it is far from Soul Eater. \n

As you can see from the title itself, this is not soul eater in both story and mood.
Story wise it was (7/10)
Soul Eater NOT! takes place before main series focusing on the weapon Tsugumi Harudori, who befriends two other meisters, Meme Tatane and Anya Hepburn. All three take part in the NOT classes, as opposed to the battle-oriented EAT class taken by Maka and her friends.
This anime shows the life of NOT students who are not involved in the witch fighting and becoming a death scythe but just learning how to control their powers, especially the weapons.
Pretty boring compared to Soul Eater, true but assomeone who is reading the manga, it is actually enjoyable and cute. Do not compared this to Soul Eater because of its completely different genre and mood. NOT! is more of a highschool (well middle school, the characters are only 14) life with lots of cutesy feelings and figuring out who you are, rather than fighting witches like Maka were. 


Unfortunately, this was a big mediocre at best because of its forced cutesy moments. As someone who is reading the manga, these moments are flow naturally in the manga but seems kinda forced in the anime. For example, extending the cutesy moments when it probably work better like this, cute moment and snap gone. While this time, they make cute moment goes on forever and lose the comedy and cute effect.


ART (6/10)


This anime was also was just put into a meat grinder, stomped with a poo covered heel, then throw in with a bunch of filthy trash to launched to the sun for it can be incinerated. That's how bad the animation was for me. While it is more of school life anime, it is related to soul eater and it needs a plot! Fighting and cool ass moves with weapon was guaranteed, but with not enough budget; soul eater not! suffered badly with its really awful animation. The art looks pretty and cute though, so that's how they kinda can covered their awful animation.


SOUND (7/10)

Soul eater not! sound tracks are also mediocre.


CHARACTERS (8/10)


Characters are filled with cute girls, who are most likely in love with each other for it does contain girl/girl kiss. And there is nothing wrong with that! But I'm putting it here so people won't bash the anime for the wrong reason, bash it for the awful animation but not for the not straight moment they put.


Once again, our main characters are very cute and likeable but the true highlights of this anime was the Thompson sisters and Kim and Jacqueline backgrounds. Soul Eater NOT! main characters (maka, soul, kid, black star, Tsubaki, Ox) also make appearances. These were the one of the few things that makes this anime enjoyable.


OVERALL (7/10)


For those who read the manga or watched/read soul eater, do not expect much of this. The anime did mediocre at best.


For those who knows nothing about soul eater, expect the same but because you know nothing of the main series, you will most likely enjoy the characters and story more because you won't be moaning for the originals characters to come back.

Soul Eater NOT! was actually a pretty good series. A lot of people were dissapointed going into the actual series, as it was NOT Soul Eater. But remember, it's Soul Eater Not, it is NOT Soul Eater. 
Story- 4: The story... was fairy decent. Nothing outstanding, and it was pretty slow and standard, but I thought that for the amount of episodes the actual series had, and the kind've series it was, the story was pretty alright.
Art- 8: The series might not have had the original artsyle that the main series had, but if this series had the original artstyle, then I don't think Iwould've liked the art near as much. The art from this series is great, and it fits with the overall theme of the story. Also the backgrounds were super pretty and I really quite liked the character designs. All the characters had nice looking clothes and color schemes and I really love how the three main characters looked together on screen. Their color schemes complimented each other nicely.


Sound- 10: I have NO complaints about the sound of this series, the background music was amazing, and the opening and ending were also very nice. They fit the series very nicely. Also the voice acting was super good, and even the english dub was very nice! I really liked how everyone sounded. The voice actors made the series feel complete. 


Characters- 7: The characters in this series were great. Tsugumi, Meme, and Anya were all super fun to watch on screen and I really liked how Liz and Patty got a bit more development in this series as they were arguably the least developed main characters in the original series. I also liked Maka's role in this series as a "senpai" for Tsugumi. The characters were nice, although pretty tropey. 


Enjoyment- 8: I never really had to force myself to watch any of these episodes although they could get kind've boring at times. I quite liked every single episode.


Overall, I rate this series as a 7. Not the best, but still worth watching. It's quite cute.

Soul Eater NOT, a show most people cringe to when they simply hear the title. Now is the show really as bad as most people want to claim it is; Well yes and no. No it's not as bad because the show has some fights as well as a semi interesting plot. Yes because it just simply isn't Soul Eater (but aside from that), and the characters can be the generic moe driven scum that we have all seen and are familiar with.
Story:
So I know people probably want to give every aspect of this show a hard time, but the story is actually pretty funif you are a fan of Soul Eater. The story is a girl one day half way transforms into a weapon and now she has been sent to a special school so she can learn more about her new skill. The show is mainly about her befriending two other girls as partners, but the show doesn't just focus on that. Soul Eater NOT also has elements from Soul Eater; Since this show is a prequel, you get to see how some characters were before the main show Soul Eater starts. As well as background for characters, you do get to learn about some of the lore from Soul Eater which I thought was pretty neat


Characters:

So if you enjoy slices of life and moe culture then this show may be your cup of tea. Sure the characters are predictable and generic, but I think they were actually designed that way for comedic purposes, as in to make fun of the generic moe characters we see in every show ever. There were times when this joke did go a little too far however, and it made me want to claw my eyes out. For the most part though they were tolerable, and sometimes it was pretty funny where they took the stereotype. 


I also want to add that the main character from Soul Eater are side characters, and some of the side characters are now main characters.


Art:

This was one of the very few things that really bothered me with this show. Now, the art is not bad, but it is very different from it's parent show. Seeing some of the characters from Soul Eater stylized to look different was kinda a bad touch, but in defense they didn't look bad, just different is all.


Overall; 

If you enjoyed Soul Eater and also enjoy slices of life, this show might be worth a watch, as long you don't mind pure unfiltered moe moments.


Also since it's a prequel, it might be fun to watch this then re-watch Soul Eater, since that show is worth watching multiple times.

I don't know why people are giving negative reviews to this series. It is somewhat related to the original Soul Eater but they are of different genre. Original Soul Eater is action/comedy and this is slice of life/comedy. I read few reviews before watching this so I was prepared for the genre change.
The only similarities between these two series are DWMA and people turning into weapons. Soul Eater NOT! is a relaxing anime you can watch without sitting at the edge of your seat and biting your nails off. It has a pleasant amount of humor but the story isn't that deep which you canexpect from a slice of life anime. The art-style is nice and the animation is smooth but there should have been something deeper in this anime.\n\n
Final verdict: If you have watched the original Soul Eater and want something more relaxing and fun to watch or just happened to like slice of life animes in general... try this and I think you won't be disappointed.

I don't understand why so many people disregard this series. There is absolutely nothing bad about it. I thought it was a lot of funEater story, and we learn some things like how Sid died in Soul Eater, and about the lives of Liz, Patty, Kim, etc. before hand. The last few episodes were really intense, and I really wanted to see everyone turn out okay! And one of the episodes when one character was possessed by the main villain at the town festival had me so hyped up and I was really scared for her safety. 


Well, yeah, the story isn't always this intense. Most of it is slice of life stuff, but you learn a lot about Liz and Patty's situation, Kim's personality, and how she befriends Jackie. I give it an 8/10 . 


Art and Sound: Both 8/10

The art style is moe and very cute. It definitely fits the tone of the beginning of the story, and even hen everything was dark and intense, the colors and the sound did well to make us feel worried or scared. 


Characters: 9/10

This rank is mostly based on the supporting characters and the things we learn about them, as well as the main trio obviously. So I'll go individually, kind of. Tsugumi is a typical protagonist. She's determined, kind of shy, but very friendly and has a good heart. Nothing spectacular, but you can see the worry she has trying to make the big decision in the show, and you feel sorry for her when she puts herself down because of her more athletic friends. So she's not boring, just kind of typical. Anya is a typical tsundere rich girl. She wants to learn about "common life" but doesn't really like showing her vulnerable side. She's a fun and really cute character. Meme is my favorite of the three. She's funny, kind of stupid, really cute, and just brings a lot of the comedy between the three. Plus once you find out why she forgets so many things, it really does make sense and tie into the main plot. She really makes the trio so interesting for me. 


As for supporting characters, they're great. Liz and Patty are shown as their previous rebellious selves that care about nobody and will pick a fight with anyone they see on the street. You slowly see them turn to their more well known selves and it's really heartwarming. There are a few other characters in the show, like Akane and Clay, who guide Tsugumi through learning more about herself and what she wants to accomplish at the DWMA, and are really fun as well. 


Kim and Jackie are awesome too. You get to see Kim go from a total bully to a more cool, yet compassionate girl. You also get to see Jackie try to figure out of she loves Kim romantically, or just as a close friend and possible partner. Both of them work well of each other, and I ship it REALLY hard. 


The other main characters are not in it much other than Maka and Soul, but they are all the same as usual, so there isn't much to say. 


Overall, I really like this anime. I do not understand why so many people think it's bad, but I feel as though people are just angry because the art is different from the original and so is the tone. But it's really not. It gives good characters, a good story, and it keeps very faithful to the things within the cannon. The ending is even pretty good, maybe not great, but it still wraps the story up really nicely. I recommend any Soul Eater fans to at least give the show a chance and form their own opinions.
